captions.text:
Good morning, Hank. It's Tuesday, and in a
stunning turn of events I find myself... in
an airport.

Wardrobe change! Hank, today's video comes
to you in four very special parts. Part one:
your tour!

Hank, your tour seems to be going well. I
wish I was there, but you know what? I-I can't

sing or play an instrument, so I would be
kind of irrelevant. Reviews of your tour so

far include that it was "so fun," that people
had "the best time ever," and that you are

a "surprisingly competent musician." Which
analysis I have to say I agree with, Hank.

I mean back in 2007 when you released your
love song for Helen Hunt, I had no idea that

you could even play the guitar- let alone
write and sing. And watching that video my

main feeling wasn't like "oh this is a great
song" or anything, although it was, it was

"when did Hank get a guitar?" So, yeah, Nerdfighters,
if you're in any of these cities, go to Hank's
tour.

Part two: Batman's Just a Rich Guy With an
Affinity for Bats.

So Hank, when I showed our two competing shirt
designs to Sarah, she laughed for like eight

minutes and then finally said "Why would anyone
buy a shirt that says 'Batman's just a rich

guy with an affinity for bats'?" So, yeah.
If I can't even convert my wife, I'm concerned

about my ability to win this contest. But
both these shirts are available for preorder

until April, 25th and then they will never
be available again.... I mean unless they

are for some reason. I don't know. The future
is unpredictable.
Part three: Why We're in the Airport.

So, Hank, Sarah and I are on our way to attend
gala (gay-la) or possibly a gala (gah-la).

Hold on.... According to the dictionary, both
are acceptable. It's like GIF and JIFF. So,

we're going to a gala (gay-la) gala (gah-la)-
the word so fancy, they named it twice. This

gala (gay-la) gala (gah-la) is to celebrate
the Time 100, Time magazine's list of the

100 most important people in the world. Hank,
you might remember that ridiculously last

year, I-I was on that list. This year I have
apparently declined in importance, so didn't

make the list, but I did snag an invite to
the party! I can't tell you how excited I

am to have declined in significance, Hank.
Long may it continue. This could save me the

embarrassment of having to explain to other
members of the Time 100 exactly why I was

on the list- which happened a lot at last
year's gala (gay-la) gala (gah-la). Rand Paul,

or whatever, would be like "Who are you exactly?"
and I would be like "Oh, I'm the guy who popularized

the phrase French the Llama" and he would
be like "Yeah, that's not a thing." This year,

I don't have to do any of that stuff. When
people ask who I am, I'll just be like "I'm
Rand Paul's date."
Part four: Strange Marriages

Hank, your airport video about strange marriages
reminded me of a strange marriage I just heard

about... or at least a strange engagement.
So, many years ago, Hank, in 2008 the first

Nerdfighter gathering in Europe that I attended
happened in Amsterdam. There were like 30

or 40 Nerdfighters there and it was just kinda
like a party! And after it had been going

on for about an hour a Dutch Nerdfighter I
knew from her video series, "Best Wishes from

The Netherlands", came up to me and she was
like: "Can you introduce us to the Belgian

boys they have cute accents?" And now 7 years
later one of those Dutch girls- now woman-

is marrying one of those Belgian boys-now
man! So congratulations to them... I love

it when Nerdfighter-like turns into Nerdfighter-love.
So Hank the weirdest part is that at any one

of your concerts in the next couple of weeks
like Nerdfighters could meet and fall in love
and 7 years later get engaged!

Okay they just called my name for final boarding
call, I, uhh, oh boy. I've got like, my tux

shoes and my backpack and everything is totally
disorganized. I hope I make it to the plane,
I hope I make it to the plane..... MADE IT.
Hank, I'll see you on Friday.

comments.text: Paul Green 2016﻿
comments.author: J. Czecha

comments.text:
The shirt argument is biased in Hanks favor seeing as even though I agree 
with John I would still prefer to have a WE ARE ALL BAT PEOPLE shirt 
because the first shirt lacks nerdy appeal. If they  had made a joker 
themed shirt with the line "Does batman understand how difficult it is for 
an underfunded city like Gotham to replace roads and bridges?" The study 
would be less affected by response bias. Also a non-batman fan is less 
likely to buy a batman themed shirt so the study is still affected by  a 
voluntary response bias.﻿

perfect guy to spread the word!﻿

John, i'd just liked to tell you that Bruce Wayne doesn't like bats. The 
reason he chose to be the "Batman" is because he was afraid of bats, more 
so when he was a child, he was taught to face his fears so he dresses up 
like a bat and operates out of a bat cave. So Batman really doesn't have an 
affinity for bats, it's just what he's about.﻿

comments.author: Upsidedown Llama

comments.text:
For over a century, the Oxford English Dictionary had improperly defined a 
siphon as "A pipe or tube of glass, metal or other material, bent so that 
one leg is longer than the other, and used for drawing off liquids by means 
of atmospheric pressure, which forces the liquid up the shorter leg and 
over the bend in the pipe." This made headlines as the OED had attributed 
the operative force in a siphon to "atmospheric pressure" as opposed to the 
force of gravity. Atmospheric pressure is the same on either end, it's 
gravity that pulls the substance over the top hump

When pointed out by an old scientist in 2010, an OED Spokesperson stated:
"The OED entry for siphon dates from 1911 and was written by editors **who 
were not scientists** ... Our files suggest that no one has queried the 
definition before. We are revising that entire dictionary text now, and I 
have copied your helpful comments to the revision file, to ensure they are 
taken into account when the entry is rewritten."

A dictionary does not supersede the creator, nor does it magically have the 
power to alter reality. If I created a product called gizzy and explicitly 
stated it's pronounced with a J like jizzy, an editor in a dictionary 
company does not magically have the authority to decide my product can be 
pronounced jizzy or gizzy (with a soft g). Likewise, Steve Wilhite, who 
invented the Gif file in 1987, told the New York Times that the word is 
pronounced “jif” not “giff”. This was also expressed in print in the 
instruction manual released by his company. In fact, a very probably 
explanation for the inclusion of both pronunciations is to avoid 
controversy (though ironically it merely perpetuates it).

Using the dictionary to justify yourself is what's called an **appeal to 
authority fallacy**; a fallacy of irrelevance. X authoritative figure says 
Y, therefore Y must be true. That is **only** reliable if X authoritative 
figure is an **expert** on the matter; any reasonable person could see that 
Websters or Miriam, et cetera is not an expert on digital formats, matters 
of science, et cetera, and their word is therefore not the be-all-end-all. 
Mistakes can occur in the dictionary, and definitions do not always 
accurately reflect reality.﻿

pro-batman camp needs any help to win, "Batman is cool" isn't exactly a

gimmicky gadgets, and sweet ride to the intellectual heart of the matter, 
it's nerdfighters!﻿

comments.text:
Hi. This is something I wrote for John Green.
First of all, thank you for everything you have ever done. Everything. It's 
an honor for me to go to the book shop, buy your books, go home, get under 
a blanket and visit your amazing world. The world where you created Miles, 
Quentin, Margo, but mostly the world I fell in love with after reading THE 
FAULT IN OUR STARS.
Thank you for being an inspiration to all the people in this world, for 
making us want to become better people.
And also I just wanted to add that you are my favorite author, as well as 
you are to many others.  
Thank you for letting me see the light, even in the dark areas
Mariam Murabit﻿
